content_1: . On April 12 H5N1 flu broke out on two farms in Kyonggi-Do province. Altogether the farms housed 3,800 swine and 36 animals were infected. The infections were discovered during routine monitoring; the origin of the disease is unknown. Tests were conducted by the National Veterinary Research and Quarantine Service. Measures such as movement control inside the country and disinfection of the premises have been taken to prevent the spread of the disease.
content_2: . According to government officials, a 27-year-old man from Prey Veng province died on April 17 after contracting H5N1 bird flu. The man died of respiratory complications after experiencing a high fever. This is the 10th confirmed case of bird flu in a human since 2004 and the 8th death. “Avian Influenza H5N1 is still a threat to the health of Cambodians,” Minister of Health Mam Bunheng said in Wednesday’s statement. “I urge communities to be on the lookout for sick poultry and report poultry die-offs to the Ministry of Health or Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries hotlines, so that they can be investigated before people start to get sick.”
content_3:
. A 4-year-old patient with suspected bird flu tested negative for the disease by rapid testing, but M. Djamil hospital is waiting for the results of a test at the Center of Health Research and Development laboratory in Jakarta to confirm that the disease is not present. The patient has improved and is breathing normally. The child has been a patient at the hospital in Padang since April 20 and developed a fever along with difficulty breathing after contact with a dead chicken. The chicken has tested positive for H5N1 according to some reports.
